description.narrative: OPIC has presented to Sida a proposal for support to civil society organizations in Kosovo for the period 2016-2020, indicating greater focus on labor rights, gender equality, the empowerment of underrepresented groups and anti-corruption. This concept makes the added value of OPIC clearer, and it is evidently in line with their core activities in Sweden. The programmatic content of the project document coherent with the current program for Kosovo 2012-2015. The required total budget is 25 000 000 SEK.

Olof Palme International Center har presenterat ett förslag till Sida för insats till stöd till civilsamhällesorganisationer i Kosovo under perioden 2016-2020. Jämfört med tidigare stöd innebär förslaget ett större fokus på arbetstagares och underrepresenterade gruppers rättigheter, jämställdhet, samt antikorruption. Förslaget korresponderar därmed väl med Olof Palme International Centers kärnaktiviteter i Sverige som ökar mervärdet av insatsen. Projektet är i övrigt i enlighet med Olof Palme International Centers tidigare projekt för 2012-2015. Budgeten för projektet är 25 000 000 SEK.

The OPIC programme objective is "To see citizens, in particular women and youth, and other civil society groups be actively involved in local organisations/or networks and take an active role in governance by influencing the policies, political agendas and decisions in their favour". The OPC strategy for the Kosovo programme is focused on the following main areas of work: a) citizen participation in decision-making, b) transparency and accountability, c) socio-economic and labour rights, d) support to progressive political parties and movements. OPIC theory of change " The social transformation and development is achieved through collective organising" is valid and applicable. All reporting requirements as per the ageement conditions are met. Annual audit report is clean and no deviation from the annual work plan is reported.

Beslut om insats Support to OPIC program in Kosovo 2016-2020

description.narrative: During 2019 the project implementation was on track. During 2019 OPIC started supporting a network "Social Dialogue for Social Justice" comprised of OPIC partner organisations working on the same topic in order to share experiences and reach greater impact. This is the first time that this model of synergy, strategic alliance between CSO’s is supported in the Kosovo programme. The Palme Center facilitates participatory processes in which decision makers share information (transparency), make priorities according to proclaimed public policies and govern according to rules and procedure (accountability), engage with relevant stakeholders in the community (participation and dialogue) and influences legal framework and its implementation when it comes to labour rights. The Palme Center continued providing financial support to strengthen civil society partners and support their activities. During 2019 the Palme Center decreased its support to partner organizations in strengthening their capacities of financial management and of planning, monitoring and evaluation of their work due to the fact that most of them already have the policies and procedures. The Palme Center provided coaching of partners in becoming more representative in terms of having members and supporters, and more transparent and accountable in terms of structures for internal decision making. The dialogue meetings with each of the partners were held twice year ande they served as a base to define potential new steps inorganizational strengthening for the coming period. OPC is planning to introduce a new comprehensive PME system as of 2020, 2019 was a testing year and resultswill continuously be discussed with Sida. Annual Review Meeting was held on 31, 2019 between Sida, Johan Schmidt OPIC Coordinator for Western Balkan in Stockholm office Levend Bicaku, Local Coordinator in Pristina.At the ARM the Financial, audit and narrative reports wrere discussed.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
